content: The other answers ignore the crucial issue of time zone. A new day dawns earlier in Paris than in Montréal. So at the same simultaneous moment, the dates are different, "tomorrow" in Paris while "yesterday" in Montréal.
title: Java: check if a given date is within current month - Stack Overflow

content: Joda-Time
title: Java: check if a given date is within current month - Stack Overflow

content: The java.util.Date and .Calendar classes bundled with Java are notoriously troublesome, confusing, and flawed. Avoid them.
title: Java: check if a given date is within current month - Stack Overflow

content: Instead use either Joda-Time library or the java.time package in Java 8 (inspired by Joda-Time).
title: Java: check if a given date is within current month - Stack Overflow

content: Here is example code in Joda-Time 2.5.
title: Java: check if a given date is within current month - Stack Overflow

content:
DateTimeZone zone = DateTimeZone.forID( "America/Montreal" );
DateTime dateTime = new DateTime( yourJUDate, zone );  // Convert java.util.Date to Joda-Time, and assign time zone to adjust.
DateTime now = DateTime.now( zone );
// Now see if the month and year match.
if ( ( dateTime.getMonthOfYear() == now.getMonthOfYear() ) && ( dateTime.getYear() == now.getYear() ) ) {
    // You have a hit.
}
title: Java: check if a given date is within current month - Stack Overflow

content: What is a Null Pointer Exception, and how do I fix it?
title: java - What is a Null Pointer Exception, and how do I fix it? - Stack Overflow

content: When you declare a reference variable (i.e. an object) you are really creating a pointer to an object. Consider the following code where you declare a variable of primitive type int:
title: java - What is a Null Pointer Exception, and how do I fix it? - Stack Overflow

content:
int x;
x = 10;
title: java - What is a Null Pointer Exception, and how do I fix it? - Stack Overflow

content: In this example the variable x is an int and Java will initialize it to 0 for you. When you assign it to 10 in the second line your value 10 is written into the memory location pointed to by x.
title: java - What is a Null Pointer Exception, and how do I fix it? - Stack Overflow

content: But, when you try to declare a reference type something different happens. Take the following code:
title: java - What is a Null Pointer Exception, and how do I fix it? - Stack Overflow

content:
Integer num;
num = new Integer(10);
title: java - What is a Null Pointer Exception, and how do I fix it? - Stack Overflow

content: The first line declares a variable named num, but, it does not contain a primitive value. Instead it contains a pointer (because the type is Integer which is a reference type). Since you did not say as yet what to point to Java sets it to null, meaning "I am pointing at nothing".
title: java - What is a Null Pointer Exception, and how do I fix it? - Stack Overflow

content: In the second line, the new keyword is used to instantiate (or create) an object of type Integer and the pointer variable num is assigned this object. You can now reference the object using the dereferencing operator . (a dot).
title: java - What is a Null Pointer Exception, and how do I fix it? - Stack Overflow

content: The Exception that you asked about occurs when you declare a variable but did not create an object. If you attempt to dereference num BEFORE creating the object you get a NullPointerException. In the most trivial cases the compiler will catch the problem and let you know that "num may not have been initialized" but sometime you write code that does not directly create the object.
title: java - What is a Null Pointer Exception, and how do I fix it? - Stack Overflow

content: For instance you may have a method as follows:
title: java - What is a Null Pointer Exception, and how do I fix it? - Stack Overflow

content:
public void doSomething(Integer num){
   //do something to num
}
title: java - What is a Null Pointer Exception, and how do I fix it? - Stack Overflow

content: in which case you are not creating the object num, rather assuming that is was created before the doSomething method was called. Unfortunately it is possible to call the method like this:
title: java - What is a Null Pointer Exception, and how do I fix it? - Stack Overflow

content: doSomething(null);
title: java - What is a Null Pointer Exception, and how do I fix it? - Stack Overflow

content: In which case num is null. The best way to avoid this type of exception is to always check for null when you did not create the object yourself. So doSomething should be re-written as:
title: java - What is a Null Pointer Exception, and how do I fix it? - Stack Overflow

content:
public void doSomething(Integer num){
    if(num != null){
       //do something to num
    }
}
title: java - What is a Null Pointer Exception, and how do I fix it? - Stack Overflow

title: cryptography - What does cipher.update do in java? - Stack Overflow

content: Encrypts or decrypts data in a single-part operation, or finishes a multiple-part operation. The data is encrypted or decrypted, depending on how this cipher was initialized.
title: cryptography - What does cipher.update do in java? - Stack Overflow

content: The bytes in the input buffer, and any input bytes that may have been buffered during a previous update operation, are processed, with padding (if requested) being applied. If an AEAD mode such as GCM/CCM is being used, the authentication tag is appended in the case of encryption, or verified in the case of decryption. The result is stored in a new buffer.
title: cryptography - What does cipher.update do in java? - Stack Overflow

content: This is done so you don't have to read all of a file (for example) into memory in order to encrypt it.

content: switch javafx/jrubyfx scenes after some external event
title: java - switch javafx/jrubyfx scenes after some external event - Stack Overflow

content: Both your options (a) thread with Task and (b) thread without task are valid.
title: java - switch javafx/jrubyfx scenes after some external event - Stack Overflow

content: Recommended Solution
title: java - switch javafx/jrubyfx scenes after some external event - Stack Overflow

content: I'd choose option b (thread without a task).
title: java - switch javafx/jrubyfx scenes after some external event - Stack Overflow

content: The key part of the solution is the line:
title: java - switch javafx/jrubyfx scenes after some external event - Stack Overflow

content: Platform.runLater(() -> MyApplication.changeScene(newData));
title: java - switch javafx/jrubyfx scenes after some external event - Stack Overflow

content: Task is good, but probably not best for your situation
title: java - switch javafx/jrubyfx scenes after some external event - Stack Overflow

content: Task is good if you have something which is initiated by the UI or JavaFX thread. For example, the user clicks a button and you want to retrieve data from a server based upon that action, feeding back progress reports via messages and progress bar updates as the data is retrieved. So Task is very good for that kind of operation because it has explicit support for things such as the message feedback and progress updates as well as a well defined state model for when the task starts and completes. See invariants code example to understand how Task improves such situations: Platform.Runlater and Task Javafx.
title: java - switch javafx/jrubyfx scenes after some external event - Stack Overflow

content: However, when the initiator of the event is off the JavaFX application thread, there isn't much advantage in using a Task versus just using traditional concurrency utilities. This is because you typically don't need the extra services that the Task is providing such as the progress and message update APIs and its state machine. Also, libraries that are initiating such events typically already have their own thread model setup, so you don't need the extra threading framework provided by a Task.
title: java - switch javafx/jrubyfx scenes after some external event - Stack Overflow

content: Using Platform.runLater()
title: java - switch javafx/jrubyfx scenes after some external event - Stack Overflow

content: All you really want is a notification that something happened. Now that notification needs to occur on the JavaFX application thread as you can't manipulate items in an active scene using another thread. To get an event passed to the JavaFX application thread, you use the Platform.runLater(runnable) construct.
title: java - switch javafx/jrubyfx scenes after some external event - Stack Overflow

content: Sample Code
title: java - switch javafx/jrubyfx scenes after some external event - Stack Overflow

content: I won't write Ruby, because I really can't, but here is some code in Java to give you the gist - it's actually really simple.
title: java - switch javafx/jrubyfx scenes after some external event - Stack Overflow

content:
class DataReader implements Runnable {
    private final DataSource dataSource;

    public DataReader(String location) {
        dataSource = new DataSource(location);

        Thread thread = new Thread(this);
        thread.setDaemon(false);
        thread.start();
    }

    public void run() {
        while (dataSource.hasData()) {
            MyImmutableObject newData = dataSource.getSomeData();
            Platform.runLater(() -> MyApplication.changeScene(newData));
        }
    }
}

class MyApplication extends Application {
    public void changeScene(MyImmutableObject newData) {
        FXMLLoader loader = new FXMLLoader(
            getClass().getResource(
               "layout.fxml"
            )
        );

        UIController controller = 
            loader.<UIController>getController();
        controller.initData(newData);

        Scene scene = new Scene((Pane) loader.load());
        stage.setScene(newScene);
    }
}
title: java - switch javafx/jrubyfx scenes after some external event - Stack Overflow

content: The above sample makes use of fictional DataSource, MyImmutableObject and UIController classes and a fictional FXML template to demonstrate the concept (so the snippet is not a standalone runnable thing). The FXML loading concepts come from: Passing Parameters JavaFX FXML. The sample code creates its own thread, but if whatever you library you are using already creates threads itself (which is likely), you don't need to create another one, you can just add appropriate hooks into the existing library with Platform.runLater calls to get the event notification and passing of data between the library threads and your JavaFX application.
title: java - switch javafx/jrubyfx scenes after some external event - Stack Overflow

content: What is the purpose of @NamedArg annotation in javaFX 8?
title: java - What is the purpose of @NamedArg annotation in javaFX 8? - Stack Overflow

content: The @NamedArg annotation allows an FXMLLoader to instantiate a class that does not have a zero-argument constructor.
title: java - What is the purpose of @NamedArg annotation in javaFX 8? - Stack Overflow

content: Technical Background:
title: java - What is the purpose of @NamedArg annotation in javaFX 8? - Stack Overflow

content: The FXMLLoader creates objects using reflection. Typically, if you use a tag corresponding to a class with a constructor taking no arguments, an object is created from that class by calling Class.newInstance(), which invokes the no-argument constructor.
title: java - What is the purpose of @NamedArg annotation in javaFX 8? - Stack Overflow

content: If a class is defined only with constructors that take parameters, then this is problematic. The main issue is that the Java Language Specification does not require the names of parameters (to methods or constructors) to be retained at runtime. This means there's no direct, guaranteed, way for the FXMLLoader to determine which parameter has a given name.
title: java - What is the purpose of @NamedArg annotation in javaFX 8? - Stack Overflow

content: To make this concrete, suppose we define a Person class as follows:
title: java - What is the purpose of @NamedArg annotation in javaFX 8? - Stack Overflow

content:
package application;

import javafx.beans.NamedArg;
import javafx.beans.property.SimpleStringProperty;
import javafx.beans.property.StringProperty;

public class Person {
    private final StringProperty firstName ;
    private final StringProperty lastName ;

    public Person(String firstName, String lastName) {
        this.firstName = new SimpleStringProperty(this, "firstName", firstName);
        this.lastName = new SimpleStringProperty(this, "lastName", lastName);
    }

    // methods....

}
title: java - What is the purpose of @NamedArg annotation in javaFX 8? - Stack Overflow

content: In FXML we might try to create a Person as follows:
title: java - What is the purpose of @NamedArg annotation in javaFX 8? - Stack Overflow

content: <Person firstName="Jacob" lastName="Smith"/>
title: java - What is the purpose of @NamedArg annotation in javaFX 8? - Stack Overflow

content: This won't work, because the FXML loader has no guarantee that the runtime representation of the Person class retains the information as to which constructor parameter is firstName and which is lastName.
title: java - What is the purpose of @NamedArg annotation in javaFX 8? - Stack Overflow

content: Historical background
title: java - What is the purpose of @NamedArg annotation in javaFX 8? - Stack Overflow

content: Java 2.2 defined "Builder" classes corresponding to each control. These builder classes follow the standard builder pattern. When the FXMLLoader encounters a tag referencing a class with no zero-argument constructor, it would use the corresponding builder to create the instance.
title: java - What is the purpose of @NamedArg annotation in javaFX 8? - Stack Overflow

content: Unfortunately, the implementation of the builder classes was flawed, and they were deprecated in JavaFX 8, and will be removed in a later version (probably JavaFX 9). This left a problem for the FXMLLoader, which would no longer have builder classes to rely on for instantiating classes with no zero-argument constructor. A real example is the Color class, which has no zero-argument constructor and will have its builder class removed.
title: java - What is the purpose of @NamedArg annotation in javaFX 8? - Stack Overflow

content: @NamedArgs
title: java - What is the purpose of @NamedArg annotation in javaFX 8? - Stack Overflow

content: The fix for this was to introduce an annotation that is used to retain a name of a method (or constructor) argument at runtime. By reflection, we can query the parameter list of a constructor/method, and get the type (but not the name) of each parameter. It is also possible to query each parameter for any annotations, and get the value of those annotations. So the @NamedArg annotation was introduced specifically for the purpose of retaining a name of a parameter at runtime.
title: java - What is the purpose of @NamedArg annotation in javaFX 8? - Stack Overflow

content: Example
title: java - What is the purpose of @NamedArg annotation in javaFX 8? - Stack Overflow

content: For an example, use the Person class we introduced above:
title: java - What is the purpose of @NamedArg annotation in javaFX 8? - Stack Overflow

content:
package application;

import javafx.beans.property.SimpleStringProperty;
import javafx.beans.property.StringProperty;

public class Person {
    private final StringProperty firstName ;
    private final StringProperty lastName ;

    public Person(String firstName, String lastName) {
        this.firstName = new SimpleStringProperty(this, "firstName", firstName);
        this.lastName = new SimpleStringProperty(this, "lastName", lastName);
    }

    public final StringProperty firstNameProperty() { return firstName; }
    public final String getFirstName() { return firstNameProperty().get(); }
    public final void setFirstName(final String firstName) { firstNameProperty().set(firstName); }
    public final StringProperty lastNameProperty() { return lastName; }
    public final String getLastName() { return lastNameProperty().get(); }
    public final void setLastName(final String lastName) { lastNameProperty().set(lastName); }
}
title: java - What is the purpose of @NamedArg annotation in javaFX 8? - Stack Overflow

title: java - What is the purpose of @NamedArg annotation in javaFX 8? - Stack Overflow

content: Person.fxml:
title: java - What is the purpose of @NamedArg annotation in javaFX 8? - Stack Overflow

content:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
<?import application.Person?>
<Person firstName="Jacob" lastName="Smith" xmlns:fx="http://javafx.com/fxml/1" />
title: java - What is the purpose of @NamedArg annotation in javaFX 8? - Stack Overflow

import java.io.IOException;
import javafx.fxml.FXMLLoader;

public class Main  {

    public static void main(String[] args) throws IOException {     
        Person person = FXMLLoader.load(Main.class.getResource("Person.fxml"));
        System.out.println(person.getFirstName()+" "+person.getLastName());

content: then you see an error at runtime:
title: java - What is the purpose of @NamedArg annotation in javaFX 8? - Stack Overflow

content: Caused by: java.lang.NoSuchMethodException: application.Person.<init>()
title: java - What is the purpose of @NamedArg annotation in javaFX 8? - Stack Overflow

content: indicating the FXMLLoader is looking for a constructor taking no arguments (Person.<init>()).
title: java - What is the purpose of @NamedArg annotation in javaFX 8? - Stack Overflow

content: In JavaFX 8, you can fix the problem by specifying the name of the parameters with the @NamedArg annotation:
title: java - What is the purpose of @NamedArg annotation in javaFX 8? - Stack Overflow

content:
package application;

import javafx.beans.NamedArg;
import javafx.beans.property.SimpleStringProperty;
import javafx.beans.property.StringProperty;

public class Person {
    private final StringProperty firstName ;
    private final StringProperty lastName ;

    public Person(@NamedArg("firstName") String firstName, @NamedArg("lastName") String lastName) {
        this.firstName = new SimpleStringProperty(this, "firstName", firstName);
        this.lastName = new SimpleStringProperty(this, "lastName", lastName);
    }

    public final StringProperty firstNameProperty() { return firstName; }
    public final String getFirstName() { return firstNameProperty().get(); }
    public final void setFirstName(final String firstName) { firstNameProperty().set(firstName); }
    public final StringProperty lastNameProperty() { return lastName; }
    public final String getLastName() { return lastNameProperty().get(); }
    public final void setLastName(final String lastName) { lastNameProperty().set(lastName); }
}
title: java - What is the purpose of @NamedArg annotation in javaFX 8? - Stack Overflow

content: This will allow the FXMLLoader to load the class as required.
title: java - What is the purpose of @NamedArg annotation in javaFX 8? - Stack Overflow

content: Note that you can also fix the issue by defining a builder class, and that this also works in JavaFX 2.0 and later. The JavaFX team decided (probably correctly) that using this approach in a way that didn't suffer from the bugs that existed in the initial implementation of the builders would add too much bloat to the codebase of the framework.
title: java - What is the purpose of @NamedArg annotation in javaFX 8? - Stack Overflow

content:
package application;

public class PersonBuilder {

    private String firstName ;
    private String lastName ;

    private PersonBuilder() {   }

    public static PersonBuilder create() {
        return new PersonBuilder();
    }

    public PersonBuilder firstName(String firstName) {
        this.firstName = firstName ;
        return this ;
    }

    public PersonBuilder lastName(String lastName) {
        this.lastName = lastName ;
        return this ;
    }

    public Person build() {
        return new Person(firstName, lastName);
    }
}
title: java - What is the purpose of @NamedArg annotation in javaFX 8? - Stack Overflow

content: Using multiple constructors with one object in Java
title: Using multiple constructors with one object in Java - Stack Overflow

content: You can't use two constructors simultaneously on a single object.
title: Using multiple constructors with one object in Java - Stack Overflow

content: In your code:
title: Using multiple constructors with one object in Java - Stack Overflow

content: Student sam = new Student(12, "Alpha High School", "Biology");
title: Using multiple constructors with one object in Java - Stack Overflow

content: creates a new Student object and assigns its reference to the variable sam.
title: Using multiple constructors with one object in Java - Stack Overflow

content: On your next line:
title: Using multiple constructors with one object in Java - Stack Overflow

content: sam = new Student(154324, "Sam Bay", 3.56);
title: Using multiple constructors with one object in Java - Stack Overflow

content: This creates another Student object, separate from the first, and reassigns sam to refer to it instead. In the process, you end up orphaning the original Student and leave it open to garbage collection.
title: Using multiple constructors with one object in Java - Stack Overflow

content: What you really want to do is either pass all data required for by a Student through a single constructor, or provide getters/setters (e.g. setGradeLevel(int level)) and a layer of exceptions that prevent methods from accessing a Student object until all fields are filled. The first option is generally more sound.
title: Using multiple constructors with one object in Java - Stack Overflow

content: For example, a complete constructor would look something like this (formatted for readability):
title: Using multiple constructors with one object in Java - Stack Overflow

content:
public Student(int id, int gradeLevel, String name, 
               String school, String major, double gpa)
{
    // fill your fields in here
}

content: How do I compare strings in Java?
title: How do I compare strings in Java? - Stack Overflow

content: == tests for reference equality.
title: How do I compare strings in Java? - Stack Overflow

content: .equals() tests for value equality.
title: How do I compare strings in Java? - Stack Overflow

content: Consequently, if you actually want to test whether two strings have the same value you should use .equals() (except in a few situations where you can guarantee that two strings with the same value will be represented by the same object eg: String interning).
title: How do I compare strings in Java? - Stack Overflow

content: == is for testing whether two strings are the same object.
title: How do I compare strings in Java? - Stack Overflow

content:
// These two have the same value
new String("test").equals("test") // --> true 

// ... but they are not the same object
new String("test") == "test" // --> false 

// ... neither are these
new String("test") == new String("test") // --> false 

// ... but these are because literals are interned by 
// the compiler and thus refer to the same object
"test" == "test" // --> true 

// concatenation of string literals happens at compile time,
// also resulting in the same object
"test" == "te" + "st" // --> true

// but .substring() is invoked at runtime, generating distinct objects
"test" == "!test".substring(1) // --> false

// interned strings can also be recalled by calling .intern()
"test" == "!test".substring(1).intern() // --> true
title: How do I compare strings in Java? - Stack Overflow

content: It is important to note that == is a bit cheaper than equals() (a single reference comparison instead of a method call), thus, in situations where it is applicable (i.e. you can guarantee that you are only dealing with interned strings) it can present an important performance improvement. However, these situations are rare.
title: How do I compare strings in Java? - Stack Overflow

content: More information here: What's wrong with using == to compare floats in Java?
title: How do I compare strings in Java? - Stack Overflow

content: Java: Game loop - CPU usage is too high [duplicate]
title: Java: Game loop - CPU usage is too high - Stack Overflow

content: Why would Thread.sleep be less accurate than your code? Have you tested it and found it inaccurate? If you don't want to sleep for 20ms, split the sleep in several parts, adjusting the final sleep so the total is 20ms.
title: Java: Game loop - CPU usage is too high - Stack Overflow

content: Something like this: (I'm a C# dev so you probably have to adjust the code a little)
title: Java: Game loop - CPU usage is too high - Stack Overflow

content:
while (true)
{
    long startTime = System.currentTimeMillis();

    fenster.repaint();

    long remaining= 20 - (System.currentTimeMillis() - startTime);
    Thread.sleep(remaining - 2); // adds up to 18 ms since start if repaint took 10ms

    remaining= 20 - (System.currentTimeMillis() - startTime);
    Thread.sleep(remaining); // should be 1-2ms
}
title: Java: Game loop - CPU usage is too high - Stack Overflow

content: The code you have now will kill any laptop battery in no time, and possible give you other heating issues.
title: Java: Game loop - CPU usage is too high - Stack Overflow

content: Edit: Added fenster.repaint(). Also fixed the code so that repaint + wait totals 20ms. This code will break if repaint takes more than 18ms, so add some tests.
title: Java: Game loop - CPU usage is too high - Stack Overflow

content: Another edit to clarify: Your frame takes 10ms to paint. To achieve 50 fps, you have a total of 20ms per frame, ie if the repaint took 11ms, you must sleep 9ms before painting the next frame.
title: Java: Game loop - CPU usage is too high - Stack Overflow

content: startTime is assigned first, followed by repaint which take appx 10ms. After the repaint, we check the system timer again, and subtract the start time to get the elapsed time. We then subtract this number from 20 to get the number of ms until the next repaint.
title: Java: Game loop - CPU usage is too high - Stack Overflow

content: Then we enter sleep, but subtract 2ms to have a little margin in case the system timer is inaccurate. Again we recalculate remaining time (1-2ms) and enter another short sleep.
title: Java: Game loop - CPU usage is too high - Stack Overflow

content: All this adds up to 20ms, and you can render your next frame.
title: Java: Game loop - CPU usage is too high - Stack Overflow

content: first i want to explain some facts:
title: Recursion in Java factorial program - Stack Overflow

content:
1. Factorial is computed by the following formula : n! = n * n-1 * n-2 * n-3 * .....* 3 * 2 * 1
  2. Stack works in LIFO = last in first out or FILO = first in last out
title: Recursion in Java factorial program - Stack Overflow

content: so the code does the following it first puts all numbers from n to 1 in a stack then it pops each one and multiply it with the current result to get the factorial at the end
title: Recursion in Java factorial program - Stack Overflow

content: and by the way that is the iterative version for factorial (non-recursive), the recursive version will be like the following
title: Recursion in Java factorial program - Stack Overflow

content:
int fact(int n)
{
    int result;

   if(n==1)
     return 1;

   result = fact(n-1) * n;
   return result;
}

content: Java - multiples program
title: selection - Java - multiples program - Stack Overflow

content: First, you should note that your original question was inclusive. That is, if either x or y were themselves divisible by one of the numbers, they were included in the count.
title: selection - Java - multiples program - Stack Overflow

content: This means you cannot use z = (y-x) because that actually excludes one of them. Suppose x is 14 and y is 16. The result would be 3 - the numbers 14,15 and 16 are all divisible by either 2,3 or 5. If you calculated 'y-x' you'd only get 2 to begin with.
title: selection - Java - multiples program - Stack Overflow

content: However, this is not the only problem. The proble is that z/2, z/3 etc. do not give you the exact number of divisible numbers in the range. It's very important to consider what x and y actually were. For example, let's take two examples where the difference is 23.
title: selection - Java - multiples program - Stack Overflow

content: Example 1 - x=11, y=33
title: selection - Java - multiples program - Stack Overflow

content:
• We calculate z to be 33-11+1 (adding the one to be inclusive), which is 23.
  • Wanting to find the number of numbers divisible by 5 in this interval, we calculate z/5, which gives 4.
  • Indeed, the divisible numbers in that interval are 15,20,25,30. Four numbers, good!
title: selection - Java - multiples program - Stack Overflow

content: Example 2 - x=9, y=31
title: selection - Java - multiples program - Stack Overflow

content:
• We calculate z to be 31-9+1, which, again, is 23.
  • Once again, we calculate z/5 to be 4.
  • But this time, the numbers in that interval that are divisible by 5 are: 10,15,20,25,30. Five numbers, not 4!
title: selection - Java - multiples program - Stack Overflow

content: Note that unlike what one of the comments above said, both numbers x and y in this example are not divisible by 5. So this can't be a way to find out when it's 4 and when it's 5.
title: selection - Java - multiples program - Stack Overflow

content: So what do we do?
title: selection - Java - multiples program - Stack Overflow

content: We don't calculate the difference between x and y. This loses information. What we do is different. We find the number of numbers divisible by 5 between 0 and x (not inclusive), and between zero and y (inclusive). The difference between these two numbers is exactly the number of numbers divisible by 5 between y and x. Let's demonstrate with the two examples from above.
title: selection - Java - multiples program - Stack Overflow

content: Example 1 - x=11, y=33
title: selection - Java - multiples program - Stack Overflow

content:
• What are all the numbers k, such that k > 0 and k < x, and also k is divisible by 5? The numbers are 5 and 10. That's 2 numbers.
  • What are all the numbers j, such that j > 0 and j ≤ y, and also j is divisible by 5? The numbers are 5, 10, 15, 20, 25,30. That is 6 numbers.
  • The numbers 5 and 10, the ones we found for x, don't interest us, as they not in our interval. So out of 6 numbers, we exclude the two, and we have 4 remaining: 15, 20, 25, 30.
title: selection - Java - multiples program - Stack Overflow

content: Example 2 - x=9, y=31
title: selection - Java - multiples program - Stack Overflow

content:
• Find the k numbers for 9. These include just the number 5. So we have 1 number.
  • Find the j numbers for 31. Again it's 6 numbers 5,10,15,20,25,30.
  • Subtract 1 (this time it's just 1) from 6. We have 5. And indeed, there are five numbers between 9 and 31 which are divisible by 5: 10,15,20,25,30.
title: selection - Java - multiples program - Stack Overflow

content: So, how do we calculate it using java?
title: selection - Java - multiples program - Stack Overflow

content: For any number n, the number of numbers divisible by 5 between 0 and itself, including itself if it's divisible, is exactly n/5 (integer division). Why? I'll leave that for you to consider, but basically it's because starting from 1, there are always four indivisibles and one divisible, four indivisibles, one divisible all the way up to n.
title: selection - Java - multiples program - Stack Overflow

content: And to exclude itself, even if it is divisible, you do (n-1)/5. So if you have the number 10, and you don't want to consider it, take the number 9 and you get the correct number.
title: selection - Java - multiples program - Stack Overflow

content: Of course, all of this discussion is true for any number, not just for five. So here is a small method that calculates how many divisible numbers are between x and y:
title: selection - Java - multiples program - Stack Overflow

content:
private static long findDivisibles( long x, long y, long divisor ) {
    return y / divisor - (x-1) / divisor;
}
title: selection - Java - multiples program - Stack Overflow

content: Now you can correct your program:
title: selection - Java - multiples program - Stack Overflow

content:
long div2 = findDivisibles( x, y, 2 );
long div3 = findDivisibles( x, y, 3 );
long div5 = findDivisibles( x, y, 5 );
long div23 = findDivisibles( x, y, 2*3 );
long div35 = findDivisibles( x, y, 3*5 );
long div25 = findDivisibles( x, y, 2*5 );
long div235 = findDivisibles( x, y, 2*3*5 );

num = div2 + div3 + div5 - div23 - div35 - div25 + div235;
title: selection - Java - multiples program - Stack Overflow

content: How to run third thread when two thread done in Android

content: Pass a t1, t2 reference to t3 and inside the t3.run() wait for the other threads:
title: java - How to run third thread when two thread done in Android - Stack Overflow

content:
t1.join();
t2.join();
title: java - How to run third thread when two thread done in Android - Stack Overflow

content: Like this:
title: java - How to run third thread when two thread done in Android - Stack Overflow

content:
final Thread t1, t2, t3;

    t1 = new Thread(new Runnable() {
        public void run() {
            //do some long stuffs
        }
    });

    t2 = new Thread(new Runnable() {
        public void run() {
            //do some long stuffs
        }
    });

    t3 = new Thread(new Runnable() {
        public void run() {
            try {
                t1.join();
                t2.join();
                // t1 & t2 have finished
                // continue with t3 stuff
            } catch (InterruptedException e) {
                //handle it
            }
        }
    });

    t1.start();
    t2.start();
    t3.start();

content: Java8 Collections.sort (sometimes) does not sort JPA returned lists
title: java - Java8 Collections.sort (sometimes) does not sort JPA returned lists - Stack Overflow

content: Well, this is a perfect didactic play telling you why programmers shouldn’t extend classes not designed for being subclassed. Books like “Effective Java” tell you why: the attempt to intercept every method to alter its behavior will fail when the superclass evolves.
title: java - Java8 Collections.sort (sometimes) does not sort JPA returned lists - Stack Overflow

content: Here, IndirectList extends Vector and overrides almost all methods to modify its behavior, a clear anti-pattern. Now, with Java 8 the base class has evolved.
title: java - Java8 Collections.sort (sometimes) does not sort JPA returned lists - Stack Overflow

content: Since Java 8, interfaces can have default methods and so methods like sort were added which have the advantage that, unlike Collections.sort, implementations can override the method and provide an implementation more suitable to the particular interface implementation. Vector does this, for two reasons: now the contract that all methods are synchronized expands to sorting as well and the optimized implementation can pass its internal array to the Arrays.sort method skipping the copying operation known from previous implementations (ArrayList does the same).
title: java - Java8 Collections.sort (sometimes) does not sort JPA returned lists - Stack Overflow

content: To get this benefit immediately even for existing code, Collections.sort has been retrofitted. It delegates to List.sort which will by default delegate to another method implementing the old behavior of copying via toArray and using TimSort. But if a List implementation overrides List.sort it will affect the behavior of Collections.sort as well.
title: java - Java8 Collections.sort (sometimes) does not sort JPA returned lists - Stack Overflow

content:
interface method              using internal
                  List.sort                     array w/o copying
Collections.sort ─────────────────> Vector.sort ─────────────────> Arrays.sort

class WatermarkedCell implements PdfPCellEvent {

Whether or not you install Java 6, setting the source level to 6 will prevent you from using features like try with resources, multi-catch, or lambda expressions. However, this alone will not prevent you from using APIs defined in the newer releases.

content: In the example, the use of the boot classpath is restricted to compilations done with the sonatype-oss-release, which only requires the machine to have the older JRE (not necessarily JDK) installed only for release builds. This setting makes it easier for new users to contribute, although it means I always have to double check pull requests using the release build before merging them. I believe the balance has been successful for the long-term maintainability of the project.

content: Will threading help improve efficiency in Java?
title: multithreading - Will threading help improve efficiency in Java? - Stack Overflow

content: Does a single-threaded (main only) Java application use all available cores for computation?
title: multithreading - Will threading help improve efficiency in Java? - Stack Overflow

content: No, it will normally use a single core.
title: multithreading - Will threading help improve efficiency in Java? - Stack Overflow

content: Making a program do computations in parallel with multiple threads may make it faster, but it's not a magical solution for any kind of problem. Whether this is a suitable solution for your program depends on what your program is doing exactly, and if the algorithm can be parallelized. If, for example, you are doing lots of computations where the next computation depends on the result of the previous computation, then making it multi-threaded will not help a lot, because you can't do the computations at the same time - the next one first has to wait for the answer of the previous one. So, you first have to think about what computations in your program could be run in parallel.
title: multithreading - Will threading help improve efficiency in Java? - Stack Overflow

content: Java has a lot of support for multi-threading. You can program with threads directly, or use an executor service, or use the fork/join framework. Whatever is appropriate depends on what exactly you want to do.

content: Each component should be organized as a separate module in Intellij IDEA. One modules can use others as dependencies.

content: There are several options for connecting libraries:
title: grails - How to organize a large java project in Intellij Idea - Stack Overflow

content:
1. Add jars as global libraries in "Project structure" section in project properties. Then add that library to every module using it.

  2. Add jars as exported dependencies for a new module, and then add that module as dependency to others . Advantage of this approach is that you localize external dependencies within a single module, that can help you to make maintaining dependencies easier.

public void rotateLeft() {
  if (head != null) {                       //otherwise it is empty list
    Node temp = head;
    if (head.getNext() != null) {           //otherwise it is single item list
        head = head.getNext();
    }

    Node tail;
    if (head.getNext() != null) {
        //more than 2 items in the list
        tail = head.getNext();
    } else {
        //only 2 items in the list
        tail = head;
    }
    while (tail.getNext() != null) {
        if (tail.getNext() != null) {
            tail = tail.getNext();
        }
    }
    tail.setNext(temp);
    temp.setNext(null);
  }
}

public void rotateRight() {
  if (head != null) {                       //otherwise it is empty list
    Node tail = null;
    Node current = head;

    while (current.getNext() != null) {
        tail = current;
        current = current.getNext();
    }
    if (tail != null) {             //otherwise it is single item list
        tail.setNext(null);
        current.setNext(head);
        head = current;
    }
  }
}

content:
public class LinkedList {

    Node head;

    public LinkedList() {
        this.head = null;
    }

    public LinkedList(Node head) {
        this.head = head;
    }

    public void rotateLeft() {
        System.out.println("<-");
        if (head != null) { // otherwise it is empty list
            Node temp = head;
            if (head.getNext() != null) { // otherwise it is single item list
                head = head.getNext();
            }

            Node tail;
            if (head.getNext() != null) {
                // more than 2 items in the list
                tail = head.getNext();
            } else {
                // only 2 items in the list
                tail = head;
            }
            while (tail.getNext() != null) {
                if (tail.getNext() != null) {
                    tail = tail.getNext();
                }
            }
            tail.setNext(temp);
            temp.setNext(null);
        }
    }

    public void rotateRight() {
        System.out.println("->");
        if (head != null) { // otherwise it is empty list
            Node tail = null;
            Node current = head;

            while (current.getNext() != null) {
                tail = current;
                current = current.getNext();
            }
            if (tail != null) { // otherwise it is single item list
                tail.setNext(null);
                current.setNext(head);
                head = current;
            }
        }
    }

    public void printList() {
        Node cursor = head;
        while (cursor != null) {
            System.out.print(cursor.data + ", ");
            cursor = cursor.getNext();
        }
        System.out.println();
    }

    public void add(Object data) {
        Node temp = new Node(data);

        if (head == null) {
            head = temp;
        } else {
            Node current = head;

            while (current.getNext() != null) {
                current = current.getNext();
            }

            current.setNext(temp);
        }
    }

    public static void main(String[] args) {
        LinkedList r = new LinkedList();
        r.add(1);
        r.add(2);
        r.add(3);
        r.add(4);
        r.add(4);
        r.add(5);
        r.printList();
        r.rotateLeft();
        r.printList();
        r.rotateLeft();
        r.printList();
        r.rotateRight();
        r.printList();
        r.rotateRight();
        r.printList();
    }

}

title: Java 8 Spliterator (or similar) that returns a value iff there's only a single value - Stack Overflow

content:
static <T> Collector<T, ?, Optional<T>> singleOrEmpty() {
    return Collectors.collectingAndThen(
            Collectors.mapping(
                    Optional::of,
                    Collectors.reducing((a, b) -> Optional.empty())
            ),
            o -> o.orElseGet(Optional::empty)
    );
}

Stream.empty().collect(singleOrEmpty());   // Optional.empty
Stream.of(1).collect(singleOrEmpty());     // Optional[1]
Stream.of(1, 1).collect(singleOrEmpty());  // Optional.empty
Stream.of(1, 1).skip(1).collect(singleOrEmpty());  // Optional[1]
title: Java 8 Spliterator (or similar) that returns a value iff there's only a single value - Stack Overflow

content: For what it's worth, unless this is really performance critical code, I would personally prefer the less clever but much clearer implementation
title: Java 8 Spliterator (or similar) that returns a value iff there's only a single value - Stack Overflow

content:
static<T> Collector<T,?,Optional<T>> singleOrEmpty() {
    return Collectors.collectingAndThen(
            Collectors.toList(),
            lst -> lst.size() == 1
                    ? Optional.of(lst.get(0))
                    : Optional.empty()
    );
}

content: adding tree elements into a new list recursively-java
title: adding tree elements into a new list recursively-java - Stack Overflow

content: You have two options to traverse though the tree. These two traversals are depth-first and breadth first. This shows the basics of how each traversal works. The basics are:
title: adding tree elements into a new list recursively-java - Stack Overflow

content:
depth-first: 
Visit the starting vertex
Proceed as far as possible along a given path (via a neighbor) before “backtracking” and going along the next path

breadth-first:
visit the starting vertex
visit all of its neighbors
visit all unvisited vertices 2 edges away
visit all unvisited vertices 3 edges away, etc
title: adding tree elements into a new list recursively-java - Stack Overflow

content: Each run time is:
title: adding tree elements into a new list recursively-java - Stack Overflow

content:
Let V = number of vertices in the graph, and E = number of edges

A traversal requires O(V + E) steps.
for a dense graph, E->V2, so the worst-case bound is  O(V2)
for a sparse graph, O(V + E) << O(V2)

content: Here is the complete testcase:

content:
public static <T> Optional<T> singleOrEmpty(Stream<T> stream) {
    return stream.limit(2)
        .map(Optional::ofNullable)
        .reduce(Optional.empty(),
             (a, b) -> a.isPresent() ^ b.isPresent() ? b : Optional.empty());
}

@Test
public void test() {
    testCase(Optional.empty());
    testCase(Optional.of(1), 1);
    testCase(Optional.empty(), 1, 1);
    testCase(Optional.empty(), 1, 1, 1);
}

private void testCase(Optional<Integer> expected, Integer... values) {
    Assert.assertEquals(expected, singleOrEmpty(Arrays.stream(values)));
}

content: Is List<Dog> a subclass of List<Animal>? Why aren't Java's generics implicitly polymorphic?
title: Is List<Dog> a subclass of List<Animal>? Why aren't Java's generics implicitly polymorphic? - Stack Overflow

content: No, a List<Dog> is not a List<Animal>. Consider what you can do with a List<Animal> - you can add any animal to it... including a cat. Now, can you logically add a cat to a litter of puppies? Absolutely not.
title: Is List<Dog> a subclass of List<Animal>? Why aren't Java's generics implicitly polymorphic? - Stack Overflow

content:
// Illegal code - because otherwise life would be Bad
List<Dog> dogs = new List<Dog>();
List<Animal> animals = dogs; // Awooga awooga
animals.add(new Cat());
Dog dog = dogs.get(0); // This should be safe, right?
title: Is List<Dog> a subclass of List<Animal>? Why aren't Java's generics implicitly polymorphic? - Stack Overflow

content: Suddenly you have a very confused cat.
title: Is List<Dog> a subclass of List<Animal>? Why aren't Java's generics implicitly polymorphic? - Stack Overflow

content: Now, you can't add a Cat to a List<? extends Animal> because you don't know it's a List<Cat>. You can retrieve a value and know that it will be an Animal, but you can't add arbitrary animals. The reverse is true for List<? super Animal> - in that case you can add an Animal to it safely, but you don't know anything about what might be retrieved from it, because it could be a List<Object>.
title: Is List<Dog> a subclass of List<Animal>? Why aren't Java's generics implicitly polymorphic? - Stack Overflow

content: easiest way to refactor code from Objective-C to java?
title: ios - easiest way to refactor code from Objective-C to java? - Stack Overflow

content: The Android and iOS platforms are significantly different, so trying to port an app, line-by-line is going to produce an app of very low quality. To be honest, it's not really feasible because of the vast differences in APIs. The more "interesting" the app (in other words, the more it does), the more trouble there is in porting it. Beyond API differences, there are fundamental differences in the philosophies of the two platforms that will cause major re-design of functionality, not just code.
title: ios - easiest way to refactor code from Objective-C to java? - Stack Overflow

content: That isn't saying that apps should not be written for both platforms. Many apps are indeed available for both. But it's not a trivial or automated effort unless you started out with a cross-platform mobile development framework (for example, see this answer). Moving an app to a new platform requires redesigning the app to fit that platform before you even start looking at the code.

content: Java: Collection of classes with static methods — if static interface methods aren't the way, is there another?
title: Java: Collection of classes with static methods -- if static interface methods aren't the way, is there another? - Stack Overflow

content: It sounds to me that you have run into one of the problems that you get when you overuse / misuse static variables.
title: Java: Collection of classes with static methods -- if static interface methods aren't the way, is there another? - Stack Overflow

content: The problem you have run into is that you cannot do polymorphism for static methods in Java:
title: Java: Collection of classes with static methods -- if static interface methods aren't the way, is there another? - Stack Overflow

content:
• There is no way of saying that all subclasses of a given class must implement a given static method.

  • There is no polymorphic way of calling a static method. A call to a static method in your source code is bound at compile time to the signature of a specific static method provided by a specific class.
title: Java: Collection of classes with static methods -- if static interface methods aren't the way, is there another? - Stack Overflow

content: There is no way of saying that all subclasses of a given class must implement a given static method.
title: Java: Collection of classes with static methods -- if static interface methods aren't the way, is there another? - Stack Overflow

content: There is no polymorphic way of calling a static method. A call to a static method in your source code is bound at compile time to the signature of a specific static method provided by a specific class.
title: Java: Collection of classes with static methods -- if static interface methods aren't the way, is there another? - Stack Overflow

content: So, if countHowMany is a static method implemented by lots of classes, then you find that you have to do things like this:
title: Java: Collection of classes with static methods -- if static interface methods aren't the way, is there another? - Stack Overflow

content: int total = Class1.countHowMany() + Class2.countHowMany() + ...
title: Java: Collection of classes with static methods -- if static interface methods aren't the way, is there another? - Stack Overflow

content: ... and something like this:
title: Java: Collection of classes with static methods -- if static interface methods aren't the way, is there another? - Stack Overflow

content: for ( Class <? extends ICountMyself> currentClass : listOfUnitClasses )
title: Java: Collection of classes with static methods -- if static interface methods aren't the way, is there another? - Stack Overflow

content: simply won't work, because the class Class does not expose any of the methods of ICountMyself. (Well, you could use reflection ... but that is nasty. It is "bad design" smell to use reflection like this.)
title: Java: Collection of classes with static methods -- if static interface methods aren't the way, is there another? - Stack Overflow

content: A small improvement on your current approach would be to make countHowMany() an instance method instead of a static method. That would allow you to declare all of your classes as extends ICountMyself and then invoke the countHowMany on any instance of any of those classes. The method can be implemented as returning or updating the appropriate (class specific) static variable.
title: Java: Collection of classes with static methods -- if static interface methods aren't the way, is there another? - Stack Overflow

content: But that is still bad design smell.
title: Java: Collection of classes with static methods -- if static interface methods aren't the way, is there another? - Stack Overflow

content: The proper object-oriented way to do this is to replace the static variables. Instead, declare a class or classes that represent "collections that may contain zerklings"; e.g. "forces". Make the countHowMany method an instance method of a "force" object ... or whatever ... and have it either return the value of an instance variable associated with the collection, or calculate the value by examining all of the current elements of the "force".

title: Read numbers in a text file and calculate total in java - Stack Overflow

content:
public static void showResults(String filePath) {
    String separator = "\\s*:\\s*";
    File inputfile = new File(filePath);
    String[] heading = { "Home team", "Home score", "Away team",
            "Away score" };
    for (int i = 0; i < heading.length; i++) {
        String fmt = "%20s ";
        if (i % 2 != 0)
            fmt = "%12s ";
        System.out.printf(fmt, heading[i]);
    }
    System.out.println();
    for (int i = 0; i < 68; i++) {
        System.out.print('=');
    }
    System.out.println();
    int goals = 0;
    try (Scanner filescan = new Scanner(inputfile);) {
        while (filescan.hasNext()) {
            String aLine = filescan.nextLine();
            String[] tokens = aLine.split(separator);
            if (tokens.length == 4) {
                System.out.printf("%20s %12s %20s %12s%n", tokens[0],
                        tokens[2], tokens[1], tokens[3]);
                goals += Integer.parseInt(tokens[2]);
                goals += Integer.parseInt(tokens[3]);
            } else {
                throw new IllegalArgumentException("Invalid match count : "
                        + aLine);
            }
        }
    } catch (FileNotFoundException e) {
        System.out.println("problem " + e.getMessage());
    }
    System.out.printf("%nTotal goals = %d%n", goals);
}

content: Java FX-8: Why is EventType generic?
title: events - Java FX-8: Why is EventType generic? - Stack Overflow

content: There are Event classes, i.e. subclasses of Event, that define particular methods for that class. E.g. MouseEvent defines various methods that can be used to query the coordinates of the mouse when the event occurred (getX(), getY(), getSceneX(), getScreenX() etc); ScrollEvent defines methods to query the amount and direction of the scroll: getDeltaX(), getDeltaY(), etc).
title: events - Java FX-8: Why is EventType generic? - Stack Overflow

content: EventType is a more fine-grained object that specifies what happened. So constants of the EventType class include MOUSE_CLICKED, MOUSE_PRESSED, KEY_TYPED, SCROLL_STARTED, etc. Each of these values is associated with a particular Event subclass.
title: events - Java FX-8: Why is EventType generic? - Stack Overflow

content: The event registration method is addEventHandler(...). This method takes two parameters: an EventType (which type of event to listen for), and an EventHandler. The EventHandler is generic for obvious reasons: by defining an EventHandler<T extends Event> you get to define a handle(T event) method that takes the appropriate event object, which you can then query in the type-specific way. (E.g. an EventHandler<MouseEvent> has a handle(MouseEvent event) method, which can query the coordinates of the mouse, etc).
title: events - Java FX-8: Why is EventType generic? - Stack Overflow

content: Now, it clearly only makes sense to register an EventHandler<T> for an EventType that is associated with the Event subclass T. Furthermore, it's desirable to allow for the compiler to enforce this. By making the EventType class generic: EventType<T extends Event>, we get to let the compiler enforce this rule. MOUSE_CLICKED is not just an instance of EventType, it's an instance of EventType<MouseEvent>. Since the signature of the addEventHandler(...) method is addEventHandler(EventType<T>, EventHandler<T>), the compiler enforces that the handler is "for the same class of event" as the event type.
title: events - Java FX-8: Why is EventType generic? - Stack Overflow

content: When you combine this with using lambdas (or I suppose with type inference, in particular), it becomes quite powerful:
title: events - Java FX-8: Why is EventType generic? - Stack Overflow

content: node.addEventHandler(MOUSE_CLICKED, e -> {...});
title: events - Java FX-8: Why is EventType generic? - Stack Overflow

content: Because MOUSE_CLICKED is specifically an EventType<MouseEvent>, the compiler is able to infer that the event handler defined by the lambda is an EventHandler<MouseEvent>, and thus that e is a MouseEvent. So the compiler can now infer that
title: events - Java FX-8: Why is EventType generic? - Stack Overflow

content:
node.addEventHandler(MOUSE_CLICKED, e -> System.out.println(e.getX()));
node.addEventHandler(KEY_TYPED, e -> System.out.println(e.getText()));

content: node.addEventHandler(MOUSE_CLICKED, e -> System.out.println(e.getText()));

content: is not. If EventType were not generic, this would not be possible.

content: (The same is true without lambdas, but the less concise syntax doesn't drive the point home as well. But without EventType being generic, there would be no way for the compiler to reject

    @Override

content: Technically, EventType is used as a "Runtime-type token". It's being used not just to say which events we are interested in, but also which type of event handler should be used to handle the event. title: Pascal Triangle Not Printing Correctly in Java? - Stack Overflow

content: Your program is designed to fill in the cells of the array in a checkerboard pattern: for any two adjacent rows, one row will have non-zero entries only in even-numbered locations, and the other will have non-zero entries only in odd-numbered locations.
title: Pascal Triangle Not Printing Correctly in Java? - Stack Overflow

content: Notice that right after you do pascalTri[y][sideOne] = 1;, you decrement sideOne. That means if you are in a row that should be using odd-numbered cells, sideOne now is odd, but when you did pascalTri[y][sideOne] = 1;, sideOne was still even. So you have put an even-numbered entry in a row that should have only odd-numbered entries. That is where all the extra 1s are coming from in your output.
title: Pascal Triangle Not Printing Correctly in Java? - Stack Overflow

}

content: As you are learning, here are a few things to make your code a bit nicer:
title: Java ArrayList / RMI - Stack Overflow

content: 1- Class names should start with an uppercase, you should change itemInfo to be ItemInfo.
title: Java ArrayList / RMI - Stack Overflow

content: 2- You should generally use getters and setters, so instead of using selectedInfo.auctionID, you should use selectedInfo.getAuctionId() and selectedInfo.setAuctionId(x);
title: Java ArrayList / RMI - Stack Overflow

content: 3- You should probably consider using a switch rather than the if(scanner.next().equals("1")). Also, if you end up writng else if(scanner.next().equals("2")) then you will run into a problem, as each time scanner.next() is called, it expects input, therefore it would expect input for every if. Instead, you should have the scanner.next() outside of your switch, and then use the value which is read in. For example:
title: Java ArrayList / RMI - Stack Overflow

content:
int menuSelection = scanner.nextInt();
switch(menuSelection){
    case 1: 
        // do your stuff
        break;
    case 2:
        // do something else
        break;
    default:
        // handle any input which isn't a menu option
 }
title: Java ArrayList / RMI - Stack Overflow

content: 4- Finally, you should probably split the functionality for handling each of these menu options in to separate methods. If you put it all into this method it's going to get very big and ugly (hard to maintain) very fast.

content: Android Studio Annotation AbstractProcessor Not Found
title: java - Android Studio Annotation AbstractProcessor Not Found - Stack Overflow

content: OK, i think there are some huge misunderstandings here. First you do not have to package anything from javax.* into your application. The annotation processor runs at compile time and finishes all its job in that phase. After that, it can generate some files or configure the project etc, and those files will be packaged into the application. The annotation processor (and its javax.* dependency) will be not, since the application does not need the processor at runtime. Only the developer needs it while building the project.
title: java - Android Studio Annotation AbstractProcessor Not Found - Stack Overflow

content: The ant-based building is also deprecated. You should use Android gradle (official) or maven (unofficial) plugins.
title: java - Android Studio Annotation AbstractProcessor Not Found - Stack Overflow

content: You could ask that the processor would still need the dependency at compile time. That is true, but the javax.* classes are provided by the compiler which is building the project. In case of command-line build and IntelliJ-based IDE JDK APT provides it, in-case of Eclipse the Eclipse JDT APT plugin provides the classes.
title: java - Android Studio Annotation AbstractProcessor Not Found - Stack Overflow

content: If you want to add your annotation processor to an Android gradle project, check out our example in AndroidAnnotations. You should note the use of the android-apt plugin, which correctly adds the compile-time dependency (the processor), and also sets up the source paths so IntellJ can pick them out without manual config.
title: java - Android Studio Annotation AbstractProcessor Not Found - Stack Overflow

content: Reflections to the edit:
title: java - Android Studio Annotation AbstractProcessor Not Found - Stack Overflow

content: Unfortunately you should move the processor to a separate project. This is the only way it can work, and by the way it is the natural way for annotation processors. For example dagger and AndroidAnnotations also have this setup (but for a slightly different reason). Yeah, that means you have to add two depedendencies, but you have to deal with that. Or you can add your library as a required dep to your processor. In that case, the user only has to add the processor as a dependency, since the lib will also be added as a transitive dep. But that would be quiet weird, since the lib is the main dep here, the processor is only a tool to verify its correct usage (if i understood your edit well).
title: java - Android Studio Annotation AbstractProcessor Not Found - Stack Overflow

content: Java 8 parallel forEach progress indication
title: concurrency - Java 8 parallel forEach progress indication - Stack Overflow

content: The naive solution would be to have progress as a field of some surrounding object; then referring to progress from a lambda closure would actually mean this.progress, where this is final, thus the compiler would not complain. However, the resulting code would access the progress field from multiple threads concurrently, which could cause race conditions. I suggest restricting access to the progress field to the JavaFX application thread, by using Platform.runLater. The whole solution then looks like this:
title: concurrency - Java 8 parallel forEach progress indication - Stack Overflow

content:
// accessed only on JavaFX application thread
private int progress = 0;

// invoked only on the JavaFX application thread
private void increaseProgress() {
    progress++;
    updateProgress(progress, collection.size());
}

private void processCollection() {
    collection.parallelStream().forEach(signer -> {
        // do the work (on any thread)
        // ...

        // when done, update progress on the JavaFX thread
        Platfrom.runLater(this::increaseProgress);
    });
}
title: concurrency - Java 8 parallel forEach progress indication - Stack Overflow

content: Android Sax Parser HttpClient vs Url what are the differences
title: java - Android Sax Parser HttpClient vs Url what are the differences - Stack Overflow

content: According to this link (http://android-developers.blogspot.com/2011/09/androids-http-clients.html) the Android development team prefers that you use the Java SE http/https options while performing http/https operations instead of using the Apache HttpClient library. The reason for this is that the Apache HttpClient library is feature rich and hence more heavyweight than the java.net packages. But the later releases of Java SE contain http/https features that are still lightweight and efficient.
title: java - Android Sax Parser HttpClient vs Url what are the differences - Stack Overflow

content: Apart from this, personally, I believe that the Android developers would prefer to move away from the Apache library because Apache keeps coming out with incremental additions and keeps deprecating features which might prove to be additional overhead to the development team.

content: To answer your question, the first option would be the way the Android team would prefer you use.

content: How can I have JAX-RS return a Java 8 LocalDateTime property as a JavaScript-style Date String?
title: json - How can I have JAX-RS return a Java 8 LocalDateTime property as a JavaScript-style Date String? - Stack Overflow

content: I've never use LocalDateTime before, so I decided to do some testing. Here are my findings:
title: json - How can I have JAX-RS return a Java 8 LocalDateTime property as a JavaScript-style Date String? - Stack Overflow

content:
• Jersy 2.13 and this provider (works out the box with no extra configuration)

    <dependency>
    <groupId>org.glassfish.jersey.media</groupId>
    <artifactId>jersey-media-moxy</artifactId>
    <version>${jersey.version}</version>
</dependency>

  • Jersey 2.13 with this provider (has support for JAXB annotation - dependency on jackson-module-jaxb-annotations), with custom adapter

    <dependency>
    <groupId>org.glassfish.jersey.media</groupId>
    <artifactId>jersey-media-json-jackson</artifactId>
    <version>${jersey.version}</version>
</dependency>

public class LocalDateTimeAdapter extends XmlAdapter<String, LocalDateTime> {
    @Override
    public LocalDateTime unmarshal(String s) throws Exception {
        return LocalDateTime.parse(s);
    }
    @Override
    public String marshal(LocalDateTime dateTime) throws Exception {
        return dateTime.toString();
    }   
}

// Getter for model class
@XmlJavaTypeAdapter(LocalDateTimeAdapter.class)
public LocalDateTime getDateTime() {
    return dateTime;
}

  • Resteasy 3.0.9 with this provider, (also has support for JAXB annotation - dependency on jackson-module-jaxb-annotations), with custom adapter (See above)

    <dependency>
    <groupId>org.jboss.resteasy</groupId>
    <artifactId>resteasy-jackson2-provider</artifactId>
    <version>${resteasy.version}</version>
</dependency>

  • Both Resteasy and Jersey with this dependency (also did not work without custom config, same as last two - with adapter)

    <dependency>
    <groupId>com.fasterxml.jackson.jaxrs</groupId>
    <artifactId>jackson-jaxrs-json-provider</artifactId>
    <version>2.4.0</version>
</dependency>

    We need to make sure to register the JacksonJaxbJsonProvider

content: Storing the element type
title: Java generics for a map value - Stack Overflow

content: What you could do is pass the class of the list elements as well and store it separately:
title: Java generics for a map value - Stack Overflow

content:
private final Map<String, List<?>> properties = new HashMap<>();
private final Map<String, Class<?>> propClasses= new HashMap<>();

public <T> void put(final String key, final List<T> value, final Class<T> elementClass) {
  properties.put(key, value);
  propClasses.put(key, elementClass);
}
title: Java generics for a map value - Stack Overflow

content: As you already noted, due to type erasure you don't know the type of the list elements. Thus you need to store that class separately, hence a second map.
title: Java generics for a map value - Stack Overflow

content: To ensure that the correct class is passed, you change the put method to take a class parameter which must be of the same type as the generic type of the list. However, please note that you are still able to disable type checking by using raw types.
title: Java generics for a map value - Stack Overflow

content: Example:
title: Java generics for a map value - Stack Overflow

content:
//works because the type is Integer for the list and the class
put( "working", new ArrayList<Integer>(), Integer.class ); 

//doesn't work since Number != Integer, even though Integer extends Number
put( "error", new ArrayList<Number>(), Integer.class );
put( "still an error", new ArrayList<Integer>(), Number.class );

//careful, this compiles because the raw type List is used
//the compiler would warn us though, so don't take those warnings lightly :)
put( "raw", (List)new ArrayList<Number>(), Integer.class );
title: Java generics for a map value - Stack Overflow

content: Retrieving the lists with exact element type
title: Java generics for a map value - Stack Overflow

content:
public <T> List<T> get(final String key, final Class<T> t) {
  Class<?> propClass = propClasses.get( key );                  
  if( propClass == null || t == null || !t.equals( propClass )  ) {
    return null;
  }

  return (List<T>)properties.get(key);        
}
title: Java generics for a map value - Stack Overflow

content: When getting elements you first get the class in the according map and check whether t is the class itself or a super class. If this succeeds you get the list from the properties map and cast it to the type you need.
title: Java generics for a map value - Stack Overflow

content: t.equals( propClass ) is used, since you should not cast the list to a super type of the elements. Otherwise you'd be able to insert elements of the wrong type.
title: Java generics for a map value - Stack Overflow

content: As an example assume List<Integer>. The following would cause problems:
title: Java generics for a map value - Stack Overflow

content:
//assume this were allowed by your code 
List<Number> l = get("working", Number.class ); 
l.add( new Double( 0.5 ) ); //ouch, now we have a double in an integer list
title: Java generics for a map value - Stack Overflow

content: Retrieving the lists with element type as lower bound (read-only)
title: Java generics for a map value - Stack Overflow

content: If you want to use a super class of the element class, you could change the get() method or add a "read-only" method as follows:
title: Java generics for a map value - Stack Overflow

content:
public <T> List<? extends T> getReadOnly(final String key, final Class<T> t) {
  Class<?> propClass = propClasses.get( key );          
  if( propClass == null || t == null || !t.isAssignableFrom( propClass ) ) {
    return null;
  }

  return (List<? extends T>)properties.get(key);        
}
title: Java generics for a map value - Stack Overflow

content: If T is the element class or a super class, we allow casting to List<? extends T>. Thus the compiler allows us to access the elements using a super type but wouldn't allow us to add new elements - unless we break it by manual casts.
title: Java generics for a map value - Stack Overflow

content: Example:
title: Java generics for a map value - Stack Overflow

content:
List<? extends Number> l = getReadOnly( "working", Number.class );

//won't compile since the compiler isn't sure about the type of the list
//in our case it would actually be a List<Integer> but the compiler doesn't know that
//and thus disallows adding to the list - which is good since we'd produce a bug here
l.add( new Double(0.5));

//this would compile due to the raw type, which essentially disables type checks here
//fortunately the compiler warns us not to do this or at least be very careful
((List)l).add( new Double(0.5));

content: Java with redistributed JRE: cannot find native dependencies
title: jni - Java with redistributed JRE: cannot find native dependencies - Stack Overflow

content: The solution was that b.dll was dependend on other libraries. One of these libraries is also placed in the jre bin directory, but not present in C:\windows\system32\.
title: jni - Java with redistributed JRE: cannot find native dependencies - Stack Overflow

content: When running with the normal java command, it would first look into the system32 folder, where it couldn't find the dll. Then it looked in the folder where a.dll and b.dll are placed.
title: jni - Java with redistributed JRE: cannot find native dependencies - Stack Overflow

content: When running with the c:\data\jre\bin\java.exe command, it would first find the dll in the c:\data\jre\bin\the.dll, before looking into the folder where a.dll and b.dll are placed.
title: jni - Java with redistributed JRE: cannot find native dependencies - Stack Overflow

content: It is not allowed to redistribute the JRE without this dll. Therefore, the workaround was to explicitely load the right dll using System.load("C:/full/path/to/dll/the.dll") before loading b.dll.
title: jni - Java with redistributed JRE: cannot find native dependencies - Stack Overflow

content: It was a hard search, but the key was to use procmon and compare both executions.
title: jni - Java with redistributed JRE: cannot find native dependencies - Stack Overflow

content: fix frame rate of animated gif in Java
title: animation - fix frame rate of animated gif in Java - Stack Overflow

content: I've found this, and it works well for one gif I tried.
title: animation - fix frame rate of animated gif in Java - Stack Overflow

content: I have no idea what he's exactly doing, but at a glance it looks like if the first frame has a delay of 0 it overwrites the delay for all frames with 10. Then he 'writes' a new GIF file in memory and loads that to image.
title: animation - fix frame rate of animated gif in Java - Stack Overflow

content: [edit] I polished it up a bit and ironed out the bugs.
title: animation - fix frame rate of animated gif in Java - Stack Overflow

content:
• No proprietary API
  • Doesn't just check the 1st frame to determine if it's bugged,
  • Replaces delay only for frames where it's zero.
title: animation - fix frame rate of animated gif in Java - Stack Overflow

content:
public static Image readImgFromFile(String filename, Component parent) {
    File file = new File(filename);
    if (!file.exists()) {
        return null;
    }

    // Fix for bug when delay is 0
    try {
        // Load anything but GIF the normal way
        if (!filename.substring(filename.length() - 4).equalsIgnoreCase(".gif")) {
            return ImageIO.read(file);
        }

        // Get GIF reader
        ImageReader reader = ImageIO.getImageReadersByFormatName("gif").next();
        // Give it the stream to decode from
        reader.setInput(ImageIO.createImageInputStream(file));

        int numImages = reader.getNumImages(true);

        // Get 'metaFormatName'. Need first frame for that.
        IIOMetadata imageMetaData = reader.getImageMetadata(0);
        String metaFormatName = imageMetaData.getNativeMetadataFormatName();

        // Find out if GIF is bugged
        boolean foundBug = false;
        for (int i = 0; i < numImages && !foundBug; i++) {
            // Get metadata
            IIOMetadataNode root = (IIOMetadataNode)reader.getImageMetadata(i).getAsTree(metaFormatName);

            // Find GraphicControlExtension node
            int nNodes = root.getLength();
            for (int j = 0; j < nNodes; j++) {
                Node node = root.item(j);
                if (node.getNodeName().equalsIgnoreCase("GraphicControlExtension")) {
                    // Get delay value
                    String delay = ((IIOMetadataNode)node).getAttribute("delayTime");

                    // Check if delay is bugged
                    if (Integer.parseInt(delay) == 0) {
                        foundBug = true;
                    }

                    break;
                }
            }
        }

        // Load non-bugged GIF the normal way
        Image image;
        if (!foundBug) {
            image = Toolkit.getDefaultToolkit().createImage(filename);
        } else {
            // Prepare streams for image encoding
            ByteArrayOutputStream baoStream = new ByteArrayOutputStream();
            try (ImageOutputStream ios = ImageIO.createImageOutputStream(baoStream)) {
                // Get GIF writer that's compatible with reader
                ImageWriter writer = ImageIO.getImageWriter(reader);
                // Give it the stream to encode to
                writer.setOutput(ios);

                writer.prepareWriteSequence(null);

                for (int i = 0; i < numImages; i++) {
                    // Get input image
                    BufferedImage frameIn = reader.read(i);

                    // Get input metadata
                    IIOMetadataNode root = (IIOMetadataNode)reader.getImageMetadata(i).getAsTree(metaFormatName);

                    // Find GraphicControlExtension node
                    int nNodes = root.getLength();
                    for (int j = 0; j < nNodes; j++) {
                        Node node = root.item(j);
                        if (node.getNodeName().equalsIgnoreCase("GraphicControlExtension")) {
                            // Get delay value
                            String delay = ((IIOMetadataNode)node).getAttribute("delayTime");

                            // Check if delay is bugged
                            if (Integer.parseInt(delay) == 0) {
                                // Overwrite with a valid delay value
                                ((IIOMetadataNode)node).setAttribute("delayTime", "10");
                            }

                            break;
                        }
                    }

                    // Create output metadata
                    IIOMetadata metadata = writer.getDefaultImageMetadata(new ImageTypeSpecifier(frameIn), null);
                    // Copy metadata to output metadata
                    metadata.setFromTree(metadata.getNativeMetadataFormatName(), root);

                    // Create output image
                    IIOImage frameOut = new IIOImage(frameIn, null, metadata);

                    // Encode output image
                    writer.writeToSequence(frameOut, writer.getDefaultWriteParam());
                }

                writer.endWriteSequence();
            }

            // Create image using encoded data
            image = Toolkit.getDefaultToolkit().createImage(baoStream.toByteArray());
        }

        // Trigger lazy loading of image
        MediaTracker mt = new MediaTracker(parent);
        mt.addImage(image, 0);
        try {
            mt.waitForAll();
        }
        catch (InterruptedException e) {
            image = null;
        }
        return image;
    }
    catch (IOException e) {
        e.printStackTrace();
        return null;
    }
}
